Department of Chemistry. 43600 UKM Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia (Received 18 August 1993, revised manuscript received 22 October 1993 ) Abstract Several chemical, physical, and spectroscopic techniques were used to characterise the galliumcomponent in Ga/H-MFI(Si,Al) zeolitic propane aromatization catalysts, during their activation, stabilisation, and ageing with number of reaction-regeneration cycles. The initial gallium-modified catalysts prepared via ion exchange have a surface enriched in gallium as evidenced by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy of alpha particles. The combination of reductive reaction and oxidative regeneration conditions leads to gallium migration and redistribution in the zeolite crystals, as well as to chemical change in the nature of the gallium species. Maximum activity and aromatics selectivity are observed when non-framework dispersed galliumspecies have the highest concentration. They are associated with zeolite Bronsted acidic sites as bifunctional dual sites. Key words: acidity; aging; gallium; propane aromatization; regeneration; zeolites 1. Introduction Since about 20 years, the aromatization of C3-C4 (LPG) and CS C8 (light naphtha, LN) alkanes to yield aromatics, i.e. benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) has received increasing attention as a reforming process, because high octane BTX could be blended directly into *Corresponding author. Abdul amid et al. /Applied Cntahsis A: General 108 (1994) 85-96 the gasoline pool. BTX also provides principal building blocks for the chemical industry in its fibre, agricultural, fine chemicals, and pharmaceutical applications. H-MFI(Si,Al) is an active catalyst for the aromatization of lower alkenes and alkanes, as illustrated by the; processes known as M-Forming [ 1 ] and M2-Forming [2], developed at Mobil Oil (M =Mobil) in the 70's and early 80's. Its activity and selectivity to aromatics, that is for the conversion of propane and/or butane, are largely improved by modification with zinc or gallium. Modifications are usually achieved by ion exchange, impregnation, isomorphous substitution of framework silicon (or aluminium) by zinc or gallium, or mechanical mixing with ZnO and Ga20,. The consequences of such modifications have been reviewed recently [ 3 ] . It is now fully established that aromatization of propane and butanes benefits greatly from the combination of zeolite Bronsted sites with dehydrogenation sites provided by the zinc or gallium component. The method of gallium or zinc introduction does not appear to affect dramatically the catalytic behaviour of a stabilised Ga/H or Zn/H-MFI(Si,Al) catalyst [4]. However, the initial aromatization activity and selectivity are strongly enhanced when catalysts modified via ion exchange or impregnation are exposed to consecutive reductive (reaction) and oxidative (regeneration) conditions [5,6]. This improvement may result from the preferential accumulation of the gallium component at the zeolite crystal surface during modification [7,8], followed by subsequent gallium migration during reaction-regeneration [5,6,9]. No direct support to or proof of these proposals were available as yet. In our investigation, several chemical, physical, and spectroscopic techniques were combined to characterise the chemical state, the location, and the migration of gallium-species in (Ga/H)-MFI(Si,Al) catalysts, as a function of increasing number of reaction (reductive)-regeneration (oxidative) operation cycles. Changes in the chemical and physical state of the gallium-component are related to catalytic behaviour. 2. Experimental 2.7. Catalyst (Ga/H)-MFI(Si,Al) catalysts with 1.6 wt.-% gallium-loading were prepared by ion exchange of two MFI(Si,Al) zeolites differing by their aluminium content (Z234: Si/ Al= 18; 2356: Si /Al= 128) with a Ga(N03) 3 solution (pH=2.0; T=373 K; t=4 h). These catalysts are coded 2234 SL2 and 2356 SL1, respectively. A catalyst was also prepared with 1.0 wt.-% Ga (Z234 SL1) and another with 3.2 wt.-% Ga (Z356 SL2) [ 10] . Following impregnation, the catalysts were washed and dried at 423 K ( 12 h). The calcination temperature was increased stepwise (1 h at 673, 723, and 773 K, respectively) up to 823 K (1 h). 2.2. Characterisation Chemical analysis was performed using X-ray fluorescence (XRF), energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Chemical distributions of S.B. The morphology of the catalysts was observed by electron microscopy (SEM). Their level of structural integrity was evaluated by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and isothermal sorption of n-hexane at 363 K. The chemical modification of the gallium species was also studied further by thermal analysis (TA) and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). The spatial distribution of the gallium species and its evolution with number of reactionregeneration cycles were studied by Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy ( RBS) of alpha particles. RBS, XPS, and EDX results were also combined for this purpose. Detailed information is available elsewhere [ 10] . 2.3. Spatial distribution of the gallium species As already mentioned, unused gallium-modified catalysts are characterised by the presence of a segregated gallium-phase at the external surface of the zeolite crystals. With increasing number of reaction-regeneration cycles, gallium migration takes place, initially from the external surface of the zeolite crystals towards their intracrystalline volume. The overall dispersion and the uniformity of the gallium component distribution increase. Evidence for migration of gallium was obtained by RBS, from a detailed analysis of depth profiles for catalysts derived from zeolites 2234 SL2 (Fig. 3) and 2356 SL 1 (Fig. 4) . Changes in the spatial distribution of gallium species were also evidenced by comparing Ga/Si atomic ratios measured by techniques having different analytical probing depths, such as XPS (about 5 nm), RBS (first layer= about 70 nm), and EDX (about 200 nm) (Fig. 5) . Surface enrichment in gallium is clearly evidenced for samples 2234 SL2 and 2356 SL 1. It is always more important for catalysts derived from the parent zeolite 2356. This observation relates to the lower ion-exchange capacity and higher hydrophobicity of 2356. Quantitative analysis of the RBS profiles for gallium (Figs. 3 and 4) as well as the comparison of the Ga/Si ratios measured by XPS, RBS, and EDX (Fig. 5), which have increasing analytical probing depths, show unambiguously the redistribution of gallium species with larger number of reaction-regeneration cycles. Because of the large gallium concentration gradient in the unused 2234 SL2 and 2356 SLI samples, there is a strong driving force for gallium moving from the outside to the inside of the zeolite crystals (see for example the maximum of the Ga/Si ratio at 200 nm for 2234 R7; Fig. 3). After 9 cycles of reaction-regeneration (samples 2234 X9 and 2356 X9), gallium species are nearly homogeneously distributed. Gallium could migrate as Ga+ ions. Solid-state ion exchange is indeed a known mechanism for ion migration [ 18]. However, thermodynamic calculations also show that Ga.'O, produced by reduction of Ga203, has an equilibrium vapour pressure of about 10-' bar at 823 K, i.e., at reduction or reaction temperature [ 19] . Thus, we believe that migration of gallium may also occur by reduction of Ga"' oxidic species to Ga=O which is further sorbed in the intracrystalline volume of the zeolite. Gat as Ga20 can eventually be reoxidized to Ga"' during calcination or regeneration, and isomorphous substitution of Ga;+ in the framework can then take place to some extent, as indeed proven by "Ga MAS NMR [ 10] . Thus, it is concluded that gallium species will oscillate between the 3 + and I + oxidation states with consecutive reaction /regeneration cycles: H2(reaction) Ga2(III)03 02(regeneration) Ga2(I)O+H=O (6) Further oxidising regeneration treatments produce non-framework dispersed Gap and non-dispersed GaNp species, as discussed above. In the ageing phase, gallium as Gap and GaNp species will migrate towards the external surface with increasing number of regeneration (steaming) treatments, probably as (hydr)oxidic Ga"' species, in a way similar to that observed for Al"' extraframework species produced by steam-dealumination [ 20] . The catalytic activity and selectivity for aromatization of propane are stabilised and optimum, as a function of the number of reaction cycles, when the Gap phase reaches its maximum concentration in order to achieve the optimal amount of dual dehydrogenationacidic sites, as reported elsewhere [ 10,21 ] . It must also be recalled that ion-exchanged and/ or dispersed gallium-species have been demonstrated recently to be necessary for the heterolytic recombinative release of dihydrogen, i.e., to act as porthole for the desorption of molecular hydrogen [ 14,15,21,22] . 4. Conclusions The chemical state, distribution, and migration of gallium in (H,Ga)-MFI (Si,Al) catalysts have been characterised as a function of time-on-stream and number of regeneration cycles. A variety of aluminium and gallium species have been identified and quantified. 96 S.B. Abdul Hamid et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 108 (1994) 85-96 Surface enrichment in gallium has been demonstrated for the unused catalysts. It is more important for zeolites which possess less ion-exchange sites and are more hydrophobic. Some gallium is also substituted isomorphously in framework T-sites, as a result of the ionexchange/impregnation treatment at low pH and high temperature. Gallium migration and redistribution through the zeolite crystals is initially favoured under reductive reaction conditions. Reduction of gallium from the 3 + to the 1 + oxidation has been demonstrated to occur in reductive atmosphere, such as present during reaction. Gallium migration thus occurs as Ga' species, probably as Ga~O via the vapour phase. However, solid state ion exchange is not ruled out. Ga'+ is reoxidised to Ga'+ during regeneration. Some of the Ga3+ species can substitute isomorphously framework T-sites. Eventually, the external surface of the zeolite crystals becomes richer in Ga"' species. Catalyst activity and selectivity are stabilised, following an activation period and/or before the catalyst deactivates, when a non-framework dispersed gallium phase is present in the highest amount. Several chemical, physical, and spectroscopic techniques were used to characterise the gallium-component in Ga/H-MFI(Si,Al) zeolitic propane aromatization catalysts, during their activation, stabilisation, and ageing with number of reaction-regeneration cycles. The initial gallium-modified catalysts prepared via ion exchange have a surface enriched in gallium as evidenced by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy of alpha particles. The combination of reductive reaction and oxidative regeneration conditions leads to gallium migration and redistribution in the zeolite crystals, as well as to chemical change in the nature of the gallium species. Maximum activity and aromatics selectivity are observed when non-framework dispersed gallium-species have the highest concentration.
